articles.title: Beloved historic mill falls silent for the first time in centuries amid worsening crisis: 'There really isn't anything we can do about it'
articles.author: Samantha Hindman
articles.summary: Gayle Mill in the Yorkshire Dales, England, has been cut off from the water source that powers its Victorian-era machinery due to drought. Rising global temperatures are disrupting water cycles, making droughts more frequent and severe. The United Nations recently doubled its Youth Advisory Group on Climate Change from seven to 14 members.

articles.title: WA museum tells staff ‘almost all of us are guilty' of burning fossil fuels in ...

articles.summary: The CEO of a gas firm is not qualified to comment on the company's plan to extend production to 2070. The head of the Western Australian Museum thinks everyone is guilty of something in some way or another, as he says.

articles.title: Test for Australia after World Court's climate reset
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Some businesses are in favour of the higher end of the 65-75 per cent reduction range floated by the Climate Change Authority. Climate and environmental groups have been urging the Australian government to be ambitious and some businesses - but not all - are broadly in favour.

articles.title: Test for Australia after World Court's climate reset
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: The climate justice movement's biggest win since the Paris agreement is about to be put to the test. It's influence on major emitters, including Australia, is going to be tested in the coming days.       "This is a big win for climate justice. This is a win for the movement.

articles.title: Australia and Türkiye fight to host COP31 climate summit
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Türkiye rejects Australia's bid to host the COP31 climate summit in Adelaide, Australia's choice of host city for COP31 was chosen by the UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-Joon.       .   in the UN.

articles.title: WA museum tells staff ‘almost all of us are guilty' of burning fossil fuels in email defending Woodside partnership
articles.author: Lisa Cox
articles.summary: The Western Australian Museum's chief executive, Alec Coles, sent an email to staff defending the institution's renewed research partnership with Woodside. It came amid public criticism of the extension of the 'longstanding collaboration', in which the gas company supports the museum's biodiversity research along the WA coastline. Coles wrote to staff before a protest organised by climate activist groups for the open day at the Maritime Museum.

articles.title: Popular Sydney Beach Deploys Drones, Helicopter After Fatal Shark Attack
articles.summary: The Sept 6 incident marked the fourth fatal shark attack in Australia in 2025. Read more at straitstimes.com.au.   Â. Â   y   Y   in 2025  in Australia.  y i

articles.title: Adventures on the edge of the Indian Ocean
articles.author: Deccan Herald
articles.summary: Perth is a five-hour plane ride from Sydney. It's the most isolated major city in the world. The South-West coast of the country remains a place few people have visited. It was mind-boggling to imagine these cliffs had once been fused with the landmass of India 100 million years ago.

articles.title: No evidence exists that climate change has caused an acceleration in global sea levels, a ...
articles.author: Sott
articles.summary: There is no evidence that climate change has contributed to sea levels' acceleration, according to a new first-of-its-kind study. Global sea levels have not continued to rise at the rates predicted by many scientists. This is significantly lower than the 3 to 4 mm/year often reported by climate scientists.

articles.title: Jody fought drought for 20 years and now, her worst fears are confirmed
articles.author: Nick O'Malley
articles.summary: Jody Brown worked full-time on her family's station outside Longreach in western Queensland for 20 years. Now she's an advocate for Farmers for Climate Change and she's worried about the future of Australia in a rapidly warming world. Last year, the world had breached warming of 1.5 degrees for the first time. Since leaders signed the Paris Agreement, nations have failed to arrest carbon emissions. Professor Mark Howden said we have about three years left to halt our emissions before the 1-5 degree increase becomes locked in.

articles.title: Jody fought drought for 20 years and now, her worst fears are confirmed
articles.author: Nick O'Malley
articles.summary: When Jody Brown finished high school in 2001, she started working full-time on her family's station outside Longreach, western Queensland. The drought lasted for 20 years. By the time it ended, she had become a student of regenerative agriculture, an advocate for Farmers for Climate Change and fearful for Australia's future in a rapidly warming world. Last year, the world had breached warming of 1.5 degrees for the first time. Since leaders signed the Paris Agreement, nations have failed to arrest carbon emissions.

articles.title: Jody fought drought for 20 years and now, her worst fears are confirmed
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Australia's comprehensive outline of the climate threat is overdue, but the outlook is already diabolical, as it's already bad enough.    for the future of the planet. For more information, visit: http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/20/climate-change-threat/

articles.title: Scientists: Human Impact on Ocean Will Double by 2050
articles.author: Sonia Fernandez
articles.summary: A new UCSB study shows that human activity on the oceans is pushing the oceans toward a dangerous threshold. Humans' cumulative impact on oceans is going to double by 2050. The tropics and the poles will experience the fastest changes in impacts. Coastal areas will feel the brunt of the increased impacts. The research is published in the journal Science.

articles.title: Climate change no longer a future threat; it is a present reality!
articles.summary: 2024 will be the hottest year on record. The 10 hottest years on record all happened in the last 10 years. Last week, the UN urged countries to set more ambitious climate plans this month. Most countries have not done so despite agreeing to submit them this year under the 2015 Paris Agreement.

articles.title: 7 Undeniable Climate Change Facts That Deniers Refuse to Believe
articles.author: Oman Moments team
articles.summary: The planet's average surface temperature has increased about 1 degree Celsius since the late 19th century. Human activities like burning fossil fuels are mainly to blame for the rise in global temperatures. Recent years have seen record highs in terms of global temperatures, with recent years setting record highs.

articles.title: Africa Demands US$3 Trillion Climate Finance Revolution
articles.author: Business
articles.summary: Africa's largest climate advocacy network demands radical reforms to global finance systems. The Pan African Climate Justice Alliance delivered its demands at the official opening of the Thirteenth Conference on Climate Change and Development in Africa. The conference runs from 5-7 September in Ethiopia's capital. It serves as the technical foundation for the Second Africa Climate Summit scheduled for September 8-10 at the same venue.

articles.title: Thawing permafrost is releasing carbon dioxide locked in from the Ice Age —and it's a new climate threat
articles.author: Mahalekshmi P
articles.summary: Thawing permafrost is releasing carbon dioxide locked in from the Ice Age. Permafrost north of the Tropic of Cancer emitted a lot of carbon when the average temperature rose in the northern hemisphere after the last ice age. Most of the loss took place before 10,000 years ago, reflecting one of the largest carbon shifts of the period.

articles.title: Bulldozers decimating koala habitats, advocates warn
articles.author: Abe Maddison
articles.summary: Federally approved destruction of koala habitat in 2025 is the worst on record, conservationists say. They urge the government to act to halt the rampant decimation of koalas' habitats.    i.e. to protect koala's habitat.

articles.title: B.C. climate news: Wildfire smoke in B.C. prompts health warnings  Scientists tap fresh water under the ocean
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: There is a risk of crop failure due to climate change, according to UBC researchers. The UN's intergovernmental panel on climate change has warned for decades that wildfires and severe weather would become more frequent and intense because of climate change. The Earth is now about 1.3 C warmer than it was in the 1800s. The past 10 years are the 10 warmest on record.

articles.title: Sunscreen scandal erupts in Australia, the world's skin Cancer Epicenter
articles.author: Arab Times
articles.summary: Australia's national holiday is on September 6th. Australia is known as the "Land of the Aussies".    "Aussies" are a group of people living in Australia. They are mainly farmers and pastoralists. They live in the south of Australia.

articles.title: Pinellas County Commission Approves Lower Tax Rate for Fourth Consecutive Year Amid Fiscal Challenges
articles.author: Alice Collins
articles.summary: The Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners has tentatively approved a lowered property tax rate for the upcoming fiscal year. The board's tentative budget totals $4.9 billion, funding core public services and capital improvements. Hurricane damages reduced property tax revenue by approximately $6.7 million. The new fiscal year begins October 1.

articles.title: Humanity is rapidly depleting the world's supply of water and whole regions are drying up
articles.author: Ian James
articles.summary: There are two primary causes of the desiccation: rising temperatures and overpumping of water. Nearly 6 billion people live in 101 countries that have been losing water. Canada and Russia are losing the most fresh water, followed by the United States, Iran and India. 68% of the water the continents are losing is from groundwater depletion, which is contributing to sea level rise.

articles.title: UN Chief Argues Defense Spending Is Futile Without Climate Aid Efforts
articles.author: Daniel Foster
articles.summary: UN Chief António Guterres wants developed nations to mobilize $100 billion annually in climate finance for developing countries. Global military expenditure reached a record high in 2023, exceeding $2.4 trillion. Global security concerns of developed nations are increasingly focused on climate change.

articles.title: CPI(M) Calls for National Disaster Declaration Amid North India Flood Crisis
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Communist Party of India (Marxist) has voiced concerns over the devastating floods and landslides swamping North India. On Saturday, the party called for the Union government to label the situation a 'national disaster'. The deluge has severely impacted states like Haryana, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand, and Jammu and Kashmir.

articles.title: Flood Aftermath: Ripple Effects of Unprecedented Water Levels
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Pong and Bhakra dams in Punjab witnessed high water levels, resulting in widespread flooding across Hoshiarpur district. The number of flood-hit villages rose to 173, with significant losses reported in Garhshankar, Mukerian, Tanda, Dasuya, and Hoshipur. The deluge has severely impacted infrastructure, damaging roads, housing, and schools.

articles.title: Australia Shark Attack
articles.author: 일본 맛집여행가이드
articles.summary: A man was killed in a shark attack at Dee Why Beach in Sydney, Australia on Saturday, Sept. 6, 2025. He was consoled at the site of the attack by a man on the beach. The man was bitten by a shark. He died at the scene.

articles.title: Former Hurricane Grill Location to Get New Tenant Soon
articles.author: Matt Pfingsten
articles.summary: The former Hurricane Grill & Wings space in Heron Bay near Parkland will soon be getting a new tenant. The space has received significant interest from a number of parties. Ross Realty is narrowing down its candidates and should be able to make an announcement in the near future.

articles.title: LETTER: AP's quest to convince us of the horrors of climate change laughable
articles.author: Wooglobe
articles.summary: Richard Broadie is amused by the AP's daily quest to convince us of the horrors of climate change. Richard Broadie wonders if the AP even reads its own paper. He thinks overproduction and lower prices are probably more of a problem for farmers most years than climate change, and Iowa farmers now anticipate a record corn crop.

articles.title: ‘Our Tent Onstage Flew Off Like a Parachute': How Climate Change Hit This Summer's Tours
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: "The Tent Onstage Flew Off Like a Parachute" this summer because of climate change, according to Rolling Stone. "The tent on stage flew off like a parachute" because of the climate change this summer. "Their tent onstage flew away like a parachute."

articles.title: Wildfire smoke signals a growing climate crisis
articles.summary: Some Republican members of Congress sent a letter to the Canadian government alleging that poor forest management practices are responsible for out-of-control wildfires and for this summer's air quality problems in parts of the Midwest and Northeast. The letter fails to mention climate change. Natural Resources Canada says climate change has a profound impact.

articles.title: Cooler, windier week ahead for the Central Coast
articles.summary: A shift in the weather pattern is on the way. Cold fronts tracking from the Gulf of Alaska into the Pacific Northwest will bring rain showers as far south as Northern California and snow in the higher elevations in the northern and central Sierra Nevada. The change in weather is expected to last a few days.

articles.title: People often make wrong climate choices, a study says. One surprise is owning a dog
articles.author: CALEIGH WELLS
articles.summary: Americans don't know which personal decisions contribute most to climate change, according to a new study by the National Academy of Sciences. Climate change is caused by the release of greenhouse gases that happen when fuels like gasoline, oil and coal are burned and are mainly responsible for global warming.

articles.title: ‘Florida's in a crisis.' Broward Democrats sound alarm about Trump, DeSantis policies
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Broward elected officials discuss the negative impacts of President Donald Trump and Gov. Ron DeSantis' policies. They warn that the overall direction of the country is alarming. The terms 'fascist' and 'authoritarian' came up more than once at a 'public briefing' convened by Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz.

articles.title: Largest iceberg breaks up
articles.author: Kat Lonsdorf
articles.summary: The world's largest iceberg, A23a, calved from the Filchner-Ronne ice shelf in Antarctica in 1986. It's melting in the warmer waters of the South Atlantic Ocean. This is the normal life cycle of icebergs and doesn't appear to be part of climate change.

articles.title: ‘She knows exactly what she's doing': Thunberg's latest ‘media stunt' explained
articles.summary: Greta Thunberg is going on a second Flotilla expedition to Gaza. Israel is going to intercept the flotilla like it did last time, but James Bolt thinks she knows exactly what she's doing. He would let her land if he were the IDF.

articles.title: Continental duck numbers hold steady, feds say in status report
articles.author: Brad Dokken
articles.summary: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service reports results from its 2025 Waterfowl Population Status Report. The estimate for total breeding ducks in the traditional survey area was 34 million, unchanged from last year, but 4% below the long-term average since 1955. Mallards, at 6.6 million, were similar to 2024, and pintails were estimated at 2.2 million, 13% above 2024. Blue-winged teal numbers were 64,000, down 60% from 2024 and 69% from the long term average. The prairies have had several consecutive years of drought.

articles.title: Struggle and Resilience: Life in Tents Post-Yamuna Floods
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: More than 70 families displaced by the Yamuna floods call makeshift tents along the Delhi-Meerut Expressway their home. They cook meals over open stoves and through shared community efforts, they manage to survive daily. The recent high tides led to widespread inundation along the banks.

articles.title: Wisconsin adapting to climate change should be common sense
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: Kristin Brey is right to advocate adaptation to climate change. David Croysdale, from Mequon, has been warned about impact of climate change for decades. Here are some tips for getting your letter to the editor published in the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.

articles.title: Floodwaters recede in Punjab, Sindh braces for new inflow
articles.author: Attia Naveed
articles.summary: Punjab's rivers are seeing a gradual drop in water levels as floodwaters move downstream. Heavy inflows will enter Sindh today, raising concerns for vulnerable communities. Sindh will receive a strong flood wave of 700,000 to 800,000 cusecs by September 8. 20 million people have been rescued and 50 people have died.

articles.title: Oceans May Hit Dangerous Tipping Point By 2050
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: A new UC Santa Barbara study shows that human activity on the oceans is pushing the oceans toward a dangerous threshold. The research team also finds that the tropics and the poles will experience the fastest changes in impacts, and coastal areas will feel the brunt of the increased impacts. The authors hope that effective action can be taken to minimize or mitigate the effects of increased pressures from human activity.

articles.title: Emissions are Sparking Increases in African Heat Waves in Unexpected Ways, New Study Finds
articles.author: Chad Small
articles.summary: There was a catastrophic heat wave in Southern Europe last month and a four-year-old boy died of heat stroke in Italy. Spain experienced its longest heat wave on record and wildfires burned more than 40,000 acres in France. The frequency and intensity of heat waves in Africa have increased since the end of the 20th century due to climate change and a decline in emissions of sulfates.

articles.title: UN chief on immediate action to achieve Paris Agreement goal
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres urges immediate and drastic reductions in greenhouse gas emissions to achieve Paris Agreement goal of limiting average global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, although the world is already dangerously close to overshooting this critical threshold. He is in China for the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) Summit 2025.

articles.title: How to avoid magpie swooping this season
articles.author: Elodie Jakes
articles.summary: There have been more than 800 magpie swooping incidents reported so far this year. The breeding season for magpies is between August and October. People are more likely to get swooped in cities with more people. Magpie Alert has mapped 887 swoops since the start of 2025, with at least 16 incidents leading to serious injuries.

articles.title: Japan's Summer Hottest on Record
articles.summary: The Japan Meteorological Agency convened an expert panel on Friday to analyze this summer's record-breaking heat. From June to August, the average temperature was significantly higher than last year, making it the hottest summer since records began. The extreme heat was driven by a strong high-pressure system extending over Japan, prevailing winds and elevated sea surface temperatures.

articles.title: Expert reveals how to stay safe as magpie season swoops in
articles.author: Elodie Jakes
articles.summary: There have been more than 800 swooping incidents in Australia so far this magpie swooping season. Magpie Alert has mapped 887 swoops since the start of 2025, with at least 16 reported as having led to serious injuries. People should avoid places where magpies live and nest during breeding season to avoid a swooping attack. Business owner Hayden Hadfield used to feed his birds to deter them from attacking him.

articles.title: How to avoid, stop magpies swooping this spring: expert
articles.summary: There have been more than 800 swooping incidents this magpie swooping season in Australia. The breeding season for magpies is between August and October. People should avoid places where they live and nest during the breeding season to avoid being swooped by the birds. Magpies are more likely to attack people in cities.

articles.title: Most enduring and biggest iceberg breaks apart, with more splintering to come in death spiral
articles.author: arabtimes
articles.summary: The world's largest and most enduring iceberg is splintering into smaller pieces. It's currently drifting between the southern tips of Africa and South America. The iceberg is no longer the biggest chunk of ice floating in the oceans, but it's still the most enduring.

articles.title: When the breadbasket washes away
articles.author: Nabil Tahir
articles.summary: Flooding in one western and two eastern rivers has washed away standing cash crops in the agriculture heartland of Pakistan. It has affected lives and shelters of 4 million people in Punjab alone. Pakistan Business Forum has called for the immediate declaration of an agricultural emergency.

articles.title: Heat, Dust, and Long Drives: How Aussie Roads Affect the G4KG Engine
articles.summary: The G4KG Engine in an iLoad Hyundai is not immune to the harsh Australian driving conditions. The heat, dust, humidity, coastal humidity, and inland dust are stressors on the engine. It's important to keep the heat under control and keep the coolant and coolant under control. Air filters need replacing and seals need checking.

articles.title: Where is Frying Pan Lake, the largest natural hot spring on Earth found and unbelievable facts about it
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Frying Pan Lake is the largest natural hot spring in the world. It is located in the Waimangu Volcanic Rift Valley in New Zealand's North Island and spans over 2,000 square kilometers. It's located in a geothermal marvel.

articles.title: Rapid glacier melting in Arunachal Pradesh sparks flash flood concerns
articles.author: Ne Now News
articles.summary: There is a record 1.5-metre ice loss at the Khangri glacier in Tawang's Gorichen mountain region in Arunachal Pradesh. Satellite data from Sentinel-2 spanning 2016 to 2025 reveal a growing number of pro-glacial lakes and retreat of the glacier under the Mago Chu basin. Central Water Commission reports that over 400 glacial lakes across India are showing concerning expansion trends.

articles.title: California prison system beginning $38M pilot project to test ways to keep cells cooler at 3 prisons
articles.author: Ric Francis Ap
articles.summary: California's prison officials plan to embark on a $38 million pilot project to figure out how to keep their prison cells cool. It comes after years of complaints from prisoners about dangerous temperatures during the state's brutal summer heat waves and warnings that the problem will only get worse as the planet warms.

articles.title: Warming temperatures may impact animals' reproduction, survival: Studies
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Temperatures can change how a species reproduces. One reptilian species is more resilient to climate change, while the other shows a 'sex reversal' with a biological male growing into a functional female. Findings have profound implications for an increasingly warmer future.

articles.title: Indo-Gangetic Plains experiencing more intense and frequent fog episodes: WMO
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: The Indo-Gangetic Plain (IGP) has experienced a rise in air pollution and winter fog episodes, according to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). WMO said fog's growing frequency and duration are linked to ever-increasing human activities and regional environmental changes.

articles.title: What next after Uganda reels from extreme weather blows?
articles.author: Daily Monitor
articles.summary: Uganda has become a hotspot for climate-induced disasters in recent years. Communities that once thrived on agriculture are now grappling with threats of floods, droughts, landslides, and violent storms. Despite repeated calamities, the government's response has often been slow and fragmented.

articles.title: In Greenland, Independence Lives in Uncertainty and Expectation
articles.author: Le Figaro
articles.summary: Greenland is in the fog due to climate change, Denmark's sovereignty and Donald Trump's territorial appetite.      Â   in the view of   John Sutter.  in this article.  In this view, Greenland sails in fog.

articles.title: Shark Attack: Sydney Surfer Killed – Beach Closed
articles.author: Luis Mendoza
articles.summary: A surfer was fatally attacked by a shark at Long Reef Beach, near Dee Why in Sydney on Saturday. Two weeks ago, a surfer survived a similar attack at Cabarita Beach. The future of shark safety lies in embracing advanced technologies and data analytics. Public education and responsible tourism practices are also important.

articles.title: Fatal Shark Encounter Claims Life Off Sydney Coast: Suspected Attack Highlights Ocean Risks
articles.author: Omar El Sayed
articles.summary: A 35-year-old male surfer died after a shark attack off the coast of Sydney, Australia on September 6, 2025. It is the first fatal shark bite in the Sydney region for the year. The location of the attack, near Green Island, is a popular surfing spot and a potential feeding ground for sharks.

articles.title: Turning the Tide: Harnessing Positive Tipping Points to Combat Climate Change
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: There is a threat of crossing negative climate tipping points, such as ocean current collapse and Amazon rainforest dieback. There is a pathway to optimism through positive tipping points where shifts to zero-emission behaviors and technologies become self-sustaining. Policies and social activism play critical roles in this process. Norway's transition to electric vehicles and the UK's move away from coal have driven significant progress.

articles.title: There Is No Cataclysmic Sea Level Rise
articles.summary: Dutch researchers compared projections from the UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change against real-world measurements. They found that 95% of the suitable locations show no statistically significant acceleration of the rate of sea level rise. The majority of the local causes of rapid sea-level rise are non-climatic.

articles.title: Untouched Ecosystems Face Alarming Insect Decline: Study
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Insect populations are declining even in relatively undisturbed landscapes. Keith Sockman quantified the abundance of flying insects during 15 seasons between 2004 and 2024 on a subalpine meadow in Colorado. He discovered an average annual decline of 6.6% in insect abundance, amounting to a 72.4% drop over the 20-year period.

articles.title: Send in your questions for the Guardian's climate assembly panel
articles.author: Guardian community team
articles.summary: The Trump administration has declared war on climate progress. A growing lobby of economic and political denial has been empowered by the Trump administration. Around the world, a growing number of lawsuits are being used against governments over climate change.    .   in the last few years we've witnessed a shift away from progress we need to avert climate disaster.

articles.title: North America Key To Asia's Monsoons, Climate Insights
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Scientists from the University of Bristol and the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research (ITP) from the Chinese Academy of Sciences have published a study in the journal Science Advances. They found the existence of the North American continent has teleconnections across the Pacific Ocean and strengthens the East and South Asian summer monsoon rainfall.

articles.title: Bushfires NT Alert: Kintore Rd, Lake Mackay
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: A fire has started on the Kintore Road between Papunya and Mount Liebig. The fire is spreading on one or more fronts and effective containment strategies are not in place for the entire perimeter. Smoke from the fire may affect visibility. Firefighting crews may be working close to the roadside.

articles.title: From ski trails to hiking paths, extreme heat is reshaping recreation, and our attitudes
articles.author: News-Press Now
articles.summary: Extreme heat is reshaping recreation and our attitudes. Rising temps fuel greater concern about climate change than wildfires or hurricanes. In south-central, the amount of snowfall in the winters is not the same as in previous years, which is changing people's attitudes.

articles.title: A nice lead-in to the weekend
articles.summary: The air quality is getting better in Calgary. The temperatures are climbing during the day and the temperatures are getting better.       in Calgary, Alberta. In Calgary, the temperature is climbing. In the city, the air quality's getting better and the air is cleaner.

articles.title: Heed voices of the young on climate change, Asean urged
articles.author: The Star
articles.summary: Asean children and youth call on the region to act on climate change or risk condemning the region's future generations to its worst impacts, says Asean Children and Youth Council.       .   in this article. Read full story.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning after witnessing 'very shocking' phenomenon in Arctic: 'It was not just a marginal record'
articles.author: Michael Muir
articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest year on record in the Arctic. Svalbard lost 1% of its ice cover in six weeks, equivalent to 62 gigatons, raising global sea levels by 0.16 millimeters. The Arctic is heating up faster than anywhere else. This will accelerate the loss of sea ice and raise sea levels.

articles.title: Mandatory assessments vital to curb climate disasters, say experts
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: Environmental and climate activists call for mandatory environmental impact assessments (EIAs) before approving any new housing scheme or commercial venture in Pakistan. They warn that unchecked construction is undermining Pakistan's resilience against floods, landslides and torrential rains. Pakistan is the world's fifth-largest emitter of methane due to the unsafe dumping of urban solid waste.

articles.title: Climate change: Future projections
articles.author: Our Reporter
articles.summary: According to the World Meteorological Organization, there is an 86% chance that at least one of the next five years will exceed 1.5°C above the pre-industrial level. There is a 70% chance the five-year average warming for 2025-2029 will be above 1. 5°C. As global temperatures continue to rise, we can expect more frequent and intense heatwaves, droughts, and storms. The Arctic is predicted to warm at a rate more than three and a half times the global average. The consequences of climate change will be far-reaching and devastating if left unchecked. Government, industries, and individuals work together to reduce emissions, improve energy

articles.title: Population Growth Drives Species Decline: 2025 Report
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: On this National Threatened Species Day, Sustainable Population Australia draws focus to the ongoing decline of Australia's biodiversity. Australia State of the Environment Report 2021 notes that human population growth contributes to pressures on the environment and has 'very high impact' on biodiversity. SPA's Position Statement has attracted 20,000 signatures calling for a return to a net annual migration rate of less than 70,000.

articles.title: Oceans could reach a dangerous tipping point by 2050
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Human impacts on oceans will double by 2050, according to UC Santa Barbara researchers.   -       .   by 2050.  by the year 2050, the human impact on the oceans will be twice as big as it was in the past.

articles.title: Changing climate threatens wetlands in Turkish capital Ankara
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Lake Mogan in Golbasi, in Ankara's southern suburbs, is struggling through a dry season due to drought. The August 2024-July 2025 period has been one of the driest in the past 65 years in Türkiye. Nearly 70 percent of the country is under severe or exceptional drought.

articles.title: Fatal 2024 Australian agricultural aircraft crash likely triggered by cockpit warning: report
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: The accident occurred on Feb. 10, 2024 in Bourke of the Australian state of New South Wales. The pilot, the sole occupant, was killed and the aircraft was destroyed. ATSB urged pilots to climb the aircraft to a safe height before troubleshooting unexpected alerts.

articles.title: Wildfires producing ‘witches' brew' of air pollution, UN warns
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Wildfires are releasing pollutants that can wreck the air quality a continent away from the blaze. The quality of the air people breathe is interlinked with climate change and the two respect no national borders, according to the World Meteorologi­cal Organisa­tion.

articles.title: Brace for depressed short rains, warns Met
articles.author: agatha Ngotho
articles.summary: Kenya is likely to experience depressed short rains this year, with the Meteorological Department warning of prolonged dry spells and uneven rainfall distribution between October and December. Most of the Northeast, Southeastern lowlands, and coastal regions will receive below-average rainfall, while the Highlands West of the Rift Valley and parts of Northwestern Kenya may experience above-average rain.

articles.title: Africa calls for reframing global climate action with science, finance
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: African Group of Negotiators and Pan African Climate Justice Alliance call for a reframing of global climate action to be science-driven and responsive to Africa's growing vulnerability to climate change. They are speaking at the 13th Conference on Climate Change and Development in Africa in Addis Ababa, the capital of Ethiopia.

articles.title: British Countryside and Farming Suffering at the Whims of Our Politicians: Richard Negus
articles.author: British Thought Leaders
articles.summary: Richard Negus talks to NTD's Lee Hall about the growing gulf between politicians and British farming. Negus says policy choices such as rewilding or a ban on burning moorland vegetation will have a negative impact on the countryside and rural people are not listened to by government.

articles.title: 13th Conference on Climate Change and Development in Africa (CCDA-XIII) opens in Addis Ababa (UNECA - United Nations Economic Commission for Africa)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The 13th edition of the Climate Change and Development in Africa Conference officially opened today in Addis Ababa. The theme is "Empowering Africa's Climate Action with Science, Finance, and Just Transition". The three-day event brings together the participants from all over Africa.

articles.title: Humanity is rapidly depleting the world's supply of water and whole regions are drying up
articles.author: Daily Press
articles.summary: Satellites have been tracking the total amount of water held in glaciers, ice sheets, lakes, rivers, soil and the world's vast natural reservoirs underground for more than two decades. Global analysis of that data now reveals fresh water is rapidly disappearing beneath humanity's feet.

articles.title: Sun peeps out as rain takes a break in Gurgaon, but not for long
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The maximum temperature in Gurgaon reached 32.3 degrees Celsius on Saturday, up from 31 degrees the previous day. The minimum temperature settled at 25.5 degrees Celsius, which is close to the seasonal normal for this time of the year. It is two degrees below the season's average.

articles.title: Some tropical trees cool their leaves to survive the heat—but not all species have ways ...
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: As the climate warms, tropical forest trees must adapt to the heat or die. In full sun, tropical leaves can get very hot and die of heatstroke. The heatstroke can be fatal for trees in full sun in the tropical forest.
